title: Wednesday, 6th September, 2017

PM11:12am

11:12 am
PM11:12am

But shall we get into the movers Bryce?

BE11:12am

We can, certainly.

PM11:12am

Thoughts on where to start?

11:12 am
BE11:12am

ROTR bugging us about Boohoo, which came up in passing during yesterday's session.

Boohoo.Com PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 243.87, up 14.37 (+6.26%), High: 244.25, Low: 232.50, Volume: 7.40m
PM11:13am

Danger

11:13 am
BE11:13am

........... second? biggest company on Aim now? Either second or third.

PM11:13am

Blimey

PM11:14am

£2.6bn market cap

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Anyway, it's nothing to do with this (possibly historic, or possibly entirely wrong) idea that the family investigated options before the recent fundraising and small selldown.

BE11:14am

It's entirely about a Barclays shove pre results.

BE11:15am

Ahead of Boohoo’s 1H results on 27 September, we are upgrading to Overweight.
Since initiating in March, it has been clear to us that Boohoo has a competitive advantage in its supply chain and ecommerce only model that will yield share gains for many years to come, but we haven’t been able to get comfortable enough on forecasts to find the valuation appealing. This has changed. Our differentiated work tracking ComScore and Google Trends data in Boohoo’s P2 (3 months to end Aug) suggests that PrettyLittleThing continues to accelerate sequentially, is reaching material scale in the UK, and will drive upgrades at the results. We upgrade EPS by 4% in FY18/19E and sit 20% ahead of consensus EBITDA in FY18E and 22% in FY19E. Our consistent valuation framework, comparing the multiple to different earnings scenarios, now yields a risk / reward that we think stacks up. We upgrade to OW and raise our PT to 265p, based on increased confidence in current trading.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

There's some ComScore and Google Trends stuff in there, which involved Barclays analysts searching for "Nasty Gal", so I hope they had clearance from IT first.

BE11:16am

PrettyLittleThing is almost as big as Missguided in terms of users: PLT generates almost as many users and as much time spent as Missguided in the UK according to ComScore. Missguided generated revenues of c£120m in the UK in FY17. Boohoo guides for PLT to generate total revenues of c£95m in FY18E. We model c£100m in the UK alone and, with growth looking good in the US, we have £155m in total for PLT.

BE11:17am

Upgrades matter most (for now): Boohoo is an expensive stock (55.5x P/E in cal 2018). We have been consistent in our approach to valuation: comping it to internet peers on a growth adjusted basis with different earnings scenarios (full detail in note). On our higher forecasts, and with more confidence on upside cases beyond, we think the risk / reward now stacks up. There are still question marks about long term margins beyond FY18E with a new warehouse coming and limited tech spend today. But upgrades trump these concerns in our assessment of the share price performance nearer term.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

So that's that.

PM11:17am

Hmm

PM11:17am

Ive been wrong all the way up on this one

11:17 am
PM11:17am

But I still don't understand the valuation when the barriers to entry here are so low

PM11:17am

And every train platform is plastered with multiple online frock shop ads

BE11:17am

Can't remember being overly bearish, as it happens. There are a number of questions about whether you should be paying 55 times for a company that's run as a fiefdom

11:18 am
BE11:18am

But the no-label fast fashion thing has been a spectacular success.

BE11:19am

And is now being copied by lots and lots and lots of rivals. Most of which are advertising on the Tube.

PM11:19am

Someone needs to do a skyscanner type app that scoops up all the frocks across multiple sites

11:20 am
PM11:20am

I wouldn't use it. Sure. But my daughters would

PM11:20am

Thanks Kate!

BE11:20am

I'm not sure either of us are qualified to comment on the subtle granularities of the online frock market ........ I figure your 55x pays for operational excellence or something, dunno.

undefined
PM11:22am

Been through this HPE Software stuff Bryce?

PM11:22am

Which has sent Micro Focus Rocket

11:22 am
Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 2,372, up 165 (+7.48%), High: 2,438, Low: 2,247, Volume: 1.88m
PM11:23am

All the guidance etc here https://www.invest...1709060700059399P/

BE11:23am

Yeah, okay. So HPE's terrible second quarter might have been a blip

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Q3 margin recovers a lot.

BE11:24am

Guidance is downbeat though

PM11:24am

Trying to blame the blip on...

11:24 am
PM11:24am

active reduction of less profitable professional services

PM11:24am

Division revenue fell on purpose
Omg smile

BE11:25am

How, Micro Focus is a proper pain to try and explain on a daily basis as 51% of it now resides with HP shareholders (who are difficult to rationalise in the first place, having voluntarily been HP shareholders) and also because of constant index reweights and stuff.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

The idea that HPE's doing preparatory work before Micro Focus comes in doesn't seem entirely unreasonable, and that might lead to quarter by quarter disruption.

BE11:27am

It's still a business where the persistent trend is lower though.

BE11:27am

Here's Citi.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Revenues were down 2% YoY (adjusted for currency and
divestures) with rate of declined improving from -9% in 2Q17 with a strong rebound in Licence revenues (+5% adjusted for currency and divestures vs. -28% in 2Q). Operating margin was 24.9% (17.8% in last year and 24.8% in 2Q16) with trailing 12 month operating margin at 26.6% (from 23.0%). The group is guiding to HPE Software revenues (12 months ending 31 October 2017) in the range of $2,890 million to $2,960 million (ahead of Citi estimates of $2,801 million) driven by the decline in lower profitable professional services mix.

BE11:27am

HPE Software 3Q17 reported revenues were down
3% YoY (down 2% YoY when adjusted for currency and divestures) to $718 million. The rate of decline slowed from -9% YoY decline in 2Q17 (adjusted for currency and divestures). More importantly, Licence revenue was up +2% YoY (from -28% YoY in 2Q17) to $173 million. Support revenue was down 2% YoY to $391 million (flat in 2Q17) and SaaS revenues +7% YoY to $78 million (+4% in 2Q). Professional services revenue was down 23% YoY to $76 million (11% of revenues; vs. -16% in 2Q). On a trailing 12m end July 2017, the HPE Software revenues were down 3% YoY to $3,046 million.

BE11:28am

HPE Software’s operating margin improved from 17.8% in 3Q16 to 24.9% (24.8% in 2Q17). On a trailing 12m basis, the operating margins were up to 26.6% (from 23.0% last year). Whilst the press release does not highlight EBITDA margin, we expect a similar 360bps EBITDA margin improvement on a trailing 12 month basis. Micro Focus management expects HPE Software EBITDA margins (80% mature portfolio) to reach 46% by April 2021e. In our view any operational improvement in HPE Software’s margins ahead of the deal should ideally mean a quicker path to the margin story

11:28 am
BE11:28am

On a pro-forma FY18e Micro Focus shares are trading at a PE of
17.9x and EV/EBITDA of 11.7x with multiples falling to 15.6x and 10.0x, respectively, by FY21e (on our base case 35% margin for HPE Software by FY21e). On a more optimistic 46% margin for HPE Software, the shares would trade at FY21e PE of 13.1x and EV/EBITDA of 8.7x.

BE11:28am

Micro Focus shares had been weak since the trading update in
May which highlighted weakness in HPE Software revenue trends due to concerns around volatility in the Licence stream driven by short term sales execution issues and/or customer transition fears. On a pro-forma basis (including HPE Software for 12 months), we would expect low-to-mid-single digit consensus upgrades.

BE11:29am

It's an odd turn of events, incidentally, that we're getting Invensys and Autonomy back.

11:29 am
PM11:29am

Very odd

BE11:29am

Autonomy back as Micro Focus, Invensys back as Schneider-Aveva.

BE11:30am

Neither in the form they left, of course, but still .....

undefined
PM11:30am

Actually, on the subject of computing...

PM11:30am

Do you know much about quantum computing Bryce?

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Assuming you have no follow-up questions, yes.

PM11:31am

The real reason i was late starting the session is cos i was watching a Morgan Stanley video

PM11:31am

Yes, really

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Had to cos of the headline

PM11:31am

Katy and Franky explain quantum computing

PM11:31am

Sadly, can't share that cos it's a MOST vid

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Actually, i can get a screen shot

PM11:31am

PM11:04am

My fault

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Oh, hang on, they have some words as well

PM11:32am

With more companies moving quantum computers from the lab to commercial activities, we believe widespread quantum computing is about to become a reality and holds the key to double the high-end computing market from $5bn to $10bn.

PM11:32am

Quantum computing is at an inflection point - moving from fundamental theoretical research to an engineering development phase, including commercial experiments. That said, in the medium term, we see a transition period during which classical computers will simulate quantum algorithms, while genuine quantum computers are customised to fit those algorithms.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

While the classical computer is very good at calculus, the quantum computer is even better at sorting, finding prime numbers, simulating molecules, and optimisation, and thus could open the door to a new computing era. Moore's Law was the main driver of the digital revolution; we believe quantum computing could trigger the beginning of a fourth industrial revolution, with far-reaching consequences for many sectors where computing power is becoming a limitation for R&D, such as Financials, Pharma (drug discovery), Oil & Gas (well data analysis), Utilities (nuclear fusion), Chemicals (polymer design), Aerospace & Defense (plane design), Capital Goods (digital manufacturing and predictive maintenance), Artificial Intelligence, and Big Data search in general.

PM11:33am

Last block

PM11:33am

It is hard to discern among currently evolving hardware platforms, which will be resilient enough to beat classical supercomputers in the next few years, but in our view the listed companies with the most credible internal quantum computing roadmaps are IBM, Google, Microsoft and Nokia Bell Labs. We also believe that within the disruption path there is room for new companies to emerge as important players, such as D-Wave and Rigetti. Outside of tech, companies having led the charge for several years include Airbus, Lockheed Martin, and Raytheon in the aerospace and defence sector, with recent interest by Amgen and Biogen (for molecule simulation) and Volkswagen (traffic optimisation).

Life beyond transistors? Because quantum computing is not suited to all compute tasks, smartphones, PCs, and web servers storing data will continue to run on current technology. We think the high-end compute platforms could see a transition post 2025, similar to how steam engines coexisted with combustion engines and electric motors for decades before being decommissioned. In the medium term, we see incremental demand for FPGAs and GPUs (possibly benefiting Xilinx, nVidia, and maybe Intel) as more supercomputers from Atos and Fujitsu are developed to simulate the behaviour of quantum computers. If quantum computers eventually do become ubiquitous, then the growth of high-end computing systems that emulate them could be affected, hence limiting the valuations of those stocks, but this is more a post 2020 event, in our view.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Done

BE11:34am

That's just super, thanks.

PM11:34am

PM11:34am

11:34 am

BE11:35am

The popular press seems to be covering the Sports Direct AGM like it was a three-ring circus, which I guess it is.

BE11:35am

Albeit without the ringmaster. Not much we can add there, other than to say their guidance is still absolutely impossible to achieve!

11:35 am
BE11:35am

No matter how many times it's repeated.

BE11:36am

Which it was again today.

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 392.60, up 8.4 (+2.19%), High: 397.90, Low: 379.60, Volume: 923.37k
11:36 am
PM11:36am

The actual statement is here https://www.invest...1709060700039071P/

BE11:37am

Peel Hunt's consistently the most entertaining on Sports Direct. Here's Jon Prichard's note this morning.

BE11:37am

The AGM statement is typically absent of current trading news
but there is a reiteration of the rhetoric about flagship stores, the
move to upgrading the portfolio, and the guidance of EBITDA
growth. Our store visits make us pretty excited about the
prospects for Sports Direct: the Solihull store in particular is a
big step forward. The true proof that the major brands have been
impressed by Sports Direct’s merchandising and pricing will
come when we see better branded product in the core stores, and
that is a while off, but so far so good with the new flagships. If
only SPD would engage on the financials. We increase our target
price to 400p and reiterate our positive stance.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

(I've no idea if he minds being called Jon. Apologies if required.)

BE11:38am

The job is still very far from done (we hate this “we’ve already smashed it out of the park” nonsense) but the early signs from Sports Direct’s flagship stores are visually very positive. Sadly, SPD still refuses to engage on any of the financial details but in terms of the merchandising of the product and the feel of the stores, the Solihull store that we visited is material progress on the earlier flagships. The product is high quality and it avoids the discounter feel, with areas devoted to certain third-party brands exclusively. The co-location with USC and Flannels works well, although the nature of product in the latter will be eye-watering price-wise for the average Sports Direct shopper (and anyone who is not a Premier League footballer for that matter). But as a destination site it works well and the link between sports attire, leisure and fashion works well. Not every flagship will enjoy the real estate and the catchment area of Solihull, but this is the sort of store that will impress the third-party brands, and that is what this project is all about.

PM11:39am

"The co-location with USC and Flannels works well"

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Omg smile

BE11:39am

As we've said often, what works on Oxford Street probably won't work so well in the grimy story stuck in the corner of a B-grade shopping centre in Stratford, which feels like Poland in 1972.

BE11:40am

Our previous confidence in the Sports Direct machine will not return until we see quality branded product in the non-flagship stores, and that will take a while to re-emerge as Sports Direct has yet to be fully allowed off the manufacturers’ naughty step. We’d prefer management to be a bit less gung ho in its remarks about its progress: the shares won’t rerate until a clear path to former EPS levels is clear (and re-engaging with analysts would help), but in terms of forecast momentum we are well past the trough and we expect the shares to continue their good work.

11:40 am
undefined
BE11:41am

As for Barratt .........

PM11:41am

Finals here https://www.invest...1709060700029033P/

11:41 am

Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 601.00, down 23 (-3.69%), High: 611.00, Low: 595.00, Volume: 5.13m
BE11:42am

The surprise here is the lack of surprises

11:42 am
PM11:42am

£724m of cash, mind

BE11:43am

Figures are in line rather than a beat (suggesting only that management should've guided a bit lower) and the capital return plan hasn't been budged higher.

BE11:43am

Trading's stable.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

As it was in the July trading update.

BE11:44am

Here's MOST.

BE11:44am

In July, Barratt had reported 17,395 completions, including JVs (FY guidance given at 3Q: 17,350), 16,645 wholly owned completions (3Q guidance: 16,650), and an expected PBT of £765m (reported today: £765.1m); net cash was £724m (reported at FY trading update: £720m). The group had said it expected to meet its gross margin target of 20% (reported today: 20.0%), and deliver an improved ROCE of 29% (reported today: 29.8%). The total proposed dividend for FY17, including a previously announced special dividend, is 41.7p (MSe: 41.4p)

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Current trading. The group's forward sales (including JVs) were up £2.75bn, up 13.8% year on year (FY trading update: 22%; 3Q trading update: +12.7%).
Still confident outlook: "Market conditions remain good with a wide availability of attractive mortgage finance, which, alongside Help to Buy, continues to support robust consumer demand. The group said it continues to expect to deliver modest growth in wholly owned completions, with affordable completions representing a similar proportion of completions as FY17". It also said it will "continue to deliver on its strategic objectives with a particular focus on improving margin, maintaining an appropriate capital structure and delivering our Capital Return Plan".

BE11:46am

And JPM.

BE11:47am

After issuing a detailed pre-close statement, Barratt’s full-year 2017 results are in line with our expectations. As
guided, profit before tax is £765m. In line with guidance, there is a 39.0% increase in final ordinary dividend per
share to 17.1p (2016: 12.3p) together with 17.3p special dividend per share. There is no specific new guidance
for FY18 or beyond in this statement. The only comment is ‘we will continue to deliver our strategic objectives
with a particular focus on improving margin, maintaining an appropriate capital structure and delivering our
Capital Return Plan’. Given the lack of FY18 guidance, we assume longer-term standard guidance of 3-4%
volume growth each year broadly holds, which looks to be well underpinned by the order book. While the sales
rate in the first nine weeks is down fractionally against a strong comp (0.74 vs. 0.75). The total value of the
order book is, however, up strongly y/y by 13.8%, and by 7% in volume terms. We assume that this morning’s
presentation will provide us with some more information to build up a picture of where the group believes
medium-term guidance could go. On first view, this statement looks slightly underwhelming, but we would
advise waiting for the presentation contents for more clarity.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Just looking at the divi cover guidance GB Krona mentions.

BE11:49am

The board recognizes that an ongoing dividend stream is an important part of total shareholder return. As we announced in February, given the significant operational and financial improvements the group has made over the last few years, we improved and extended the Capital Return Plan that we had originally put in place in September '14. Therefore, going forward, the board is targeting a level of ordinary dividend cover of 2.5x versus 3x previously. When market conditions allow, ordinary dividends will be supplemented by the payment of special dividends. During the 4 years to November 2018, total dividend payments are expected to be around GBP 1.4 billion based on current market estimates. In accordance with the new policy, the board is pleased to announce a proposed final dividend of 17.1p per share, together with a special dividend of 17.3p per share

BE11:49am

That's from this morning's conference call.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

And looks to have been widely expected, as there wasn't a single question about it.
